the scope and effect of section 18-A of the Act. The appellant is a firm of merchants carrying on commission agency and other business at Kurnool and as such, it purchases and sells ground-nuts and other goods on behalf of principles for commission. For the year 1952-53 the Sales- tax authorities included in the appellants taxable turnover an amount of Rs. 3,45,488/12/10 representing groundnut sales and collected the tax on the total turnover from it in September, 1953 when the amount of the said tax was determined and duly adjusted. The said turnover of Rs. 3,45,488/12/10 in fact represented sales of groundnuts and not purchases and tax was recovered from the appellant on the said amount illegally inasmuch as it is only on purchase of groundnuts that the tax is leviable.

issues.text: The short question which arises in this appeal is whether the suit instituted by the appellant... is competent or not and this question has to be determined in the light of the scope and effect of section 18-A of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The short question which arises in this appeal is whether the suit instituted by the appellant, Firm of Illury Subbayya Chetty Sons, in the court of the Subordinate judge at Kurnool, seeking to recover Rs. 8,349/- from the respondent, the State of Andhra Pradesh, on the ground that the said amount had been illegally recovered from it under the Madras General Sales Tax Act, 1939 (Mad. IX of 1939) hereinafter called the Act for the years 1952-54 is competent or not

arguments.court_reasoning: s.18-A expressly and unambiguously prohibits suits to set aside or modify any assessment made under the Act, whether correct or incorrect

arguments.claim: The transactions in regard to groundnuts on which sales tax was levied were transactions of purchase and not of sale

anchor.surface_text: and on the merits it was alleged that the transactions in regard to groundnuts on which s lestax was levied and recovered from the appellant were transactions of purchase and not of sale. In this connection, the respondent referred to the fact that the appellant itself had included the transaction in question in the return submitted by it in form A and that it was making payments tentatively every month to be adjusted after the final assessment was made at the end of the year.

arguments.claim: Appellant voluntarily included transactions in returns, made tentative payments, and thus cannot contend transactions not taxable

anchor.surface_text: In this connection, the respondent referred to the fact that the appellant itself had included the transaction in question in the return submitted by it in form A and that it was making payments tentatively every month to be adjusted after the final assessment was made at the end of the year. Accordingly, the final adjustment was made in September and the total amount due from the appellant duly recovered. Thus, the appellant having voluntarily made the return and paid the taxes, it was not open to him to contend that the transactions in regard to groundnuts were not taxable under the Act.

As a result of this illegal levy, the appellant had to pay Rs. 5.398/4/3 for the said year.

arguments.court_reasoning: Expression 'any assessment made under this Act' covers all assessments by assessing authorities under the Act, correct or incorrect; distinguishes s.17(1) and s.18

court_response_anchor.surface_text: sment sought to be set aside or modified by the suit instituted an assessment made under this Act or number? It would be extremely anomalous, to hold

arguments.court_reasoning: s.17(1) and s.18 require 'purporting' due to their purpose (bar proceedings, indemnity), unnecessary for s.18-A which covers all assessments made under Act

arguments.claim: There is presumption against exclusion of civil court jurisdiction unless express or necessary implication

anchor.surface_text: In dealing With the question wether civil courts jurisdiction to entertain suit is barred or not it is necessary to bear in mind the fact that there is a general presumption that there must be a remedy in the ordinary civil courts to a citizen claiming that an amount has been recovered from him illegally and that such a remedy can be held to be barred only on very clear and unmistakable indications to the contrary.

arguments.claim: s.18-A expressly excludes civil court jurisdiction for suits to set aside or modify any assessment made under the Act

anchor.surface_text: The exclusion of the jurisdiction of Civil Courts to entertain civil causes will not be assumed unless the relevant statute contains an express provision to that effect, or leads to a necessary and inevitable implication of that nature ... Section 18-A provides that no suit or other Proceeding shall, except as expressly provided in this Act. be instituted in any Court to set aside or modify any assessment made under this Act.

arguments.claim: Act provides adequate alternative remedies via ss.11,12,12A,B,C,D and Art.136, so s.18-A bar must be given effect

anchor.surface_text: Section 11 of the Act provides for appeals to such authority as may be prescribed s. 12 confers revisional jurisdiction on the authorities specified by it s.12-A allows an appeal to the appellate Tribunal s.12-B provides for a provision by the High Court under the cases specified in it s.12-C provides for an appeal to the. High Court and s. I 2-D lays down that petitions, applications and appeals to High Court should be heard by a Bench of not less than two judges. The matter can even be brought to this Court by way of a petition under Art. 136 of the Constitution.

arguments.claim: Following Secretary of State v. Maskim Coy.: exclusion of civil jurisdiction not readily inferred but can be by express words; civil courts can check fundamental non-compliance or natural justice violation

anchor.surface_text: In Secretary of State v. Mask. Coy., 1 the Privy Council was dealing with the effect of the provisions contained in s. 188 of the Sea Customs Act VIII of 1878 . ... it is also well-settled that that even if jurisdiction is so excluded, the civil courts have jurisdiction to examine into cases where the provisions of the Act have not been complied with, or the statutory tribunal has not acted in conformity with the fundamental principles of judicial procedure.

arguments.claim: Maskim Coy. exception for natural justice etc. does not apply to mere merits error in assessment

anchor.surface_text: It is necessary to add that these observations, though made in somewhat wide terms, do not justify the assumption that if a decision has been made by a taxing authority under the provisions of the relevant taxing statute, its validity can be challenged by a suit on the ground that it is incorrect on the merits and as such, it can be claimed that the provisions of the said statute have not been complied with.

arguments.claim: Following Raleigh Investment Coy. v. Governor-General: s.67 Income Tax Act (similar to s.18-A) bars suits; 'made under this Act' refers to provenance not accuracy

anchor.surface_text: The next decision to which reference may be made was pronounced by the Privy Council in the case of Releigh Investment Coy. Ltd. v. GovernorGeneral in Council 1 . In that case the effect of s. 67 of the Indian Income-tax Act fell to be considered. ... The phrase made under this Act describes the provenance of the assessment it does not relate to its accuracy in point of law.

arguments.claim: Suit barred by s.18-A as it seeks to set aside or modify assessment made under the Act; trial court and High Court erred otherwise

anchor.surface_text: There is therefore, no difficulty in holding that this section excludes the jurisdiction of the civil courts in respect of the suits covered by it.

holdings.text: Section 18-A expressly and unambiguously excludes the jurisdiction of civil courts to entertain suits to set aside or modify any assessment made under the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Section 18-A provides that no suit or other Proceeding shall, except as expressly provided in this Act. be instituted in any Court to set aside or modify any assessment made under this Act. It is common ground that there is no express provision made in the Act under which the present suit can be said to have been filed, and so, it falls under the prohibition contained in this section.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of s.18-A shows express prohibition; overcomes presumption against ouster of civil jurisdiction.

holdings.text: The expression 'any assessment made under this Act' covers all assessments by appropriate authorities under the Act, whether correct or incorrect.

anchor.surface_text: The expression any assessment made under this Act is, in our opinion, wide enough to cover all assessments made by the appropriate authorities under this Act whether the said assessments are correct or not. It is the activity of the assessing officer acting as such officer which is intended to be protected and as soon as it is shown that exercising his jurisdiction and authority under this Act, an assessing officer has made an order of assessment that clearly falls within the scope of s.18-A.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects argument that illegal assessments are excluded; 'made under' refers to provenance/authority, not accuracy; distinguishes s.17(1) & s.18.

holdings.text: The suit instituted by the appellant is barred under s.18-A as it seeks to set aside or modify assessments made under the Act.

anchor.surface_text: There is therefore, no difficulty in holding that this section excludes the jurisdiction of the civil courts in respect of the suits covered by it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies s.18-A to facts: suit challenges assessments on groundnuts for 1952-54.

holdings.text: The Act provides adequate alternative remedies through appeals (s.11), revisions (s.12), Tribunal (s.12A), High Court (s.12B-D), and Art.136, so s.18-A bar must be enforced.

anchor.surface_text: Section 11 of the Act provides for appeals to such authority as may be prescribed s. 12 confers revisional jurisdiction on the authorities specified by it s.12-A allows an appeal to the appellate Tribunal s.12-B provides for a provision by the High Court under the cases specified in it s.12-C provides for an appeal to the. High Court and s. I 2-D lays down that petitions, applications and appeals to High Court should be heard by a Bench of not less than two judges. The matter can even be brought to this Court by way of a petition under Art. 136 of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Presence of elaborate machinery supports strict enforcement of jurisdictional bar.

holdings.text: Civil courts retain jurisdiction to examine exclusions where statutory provisions not complied with fundamentally or natural justice violated, but not for errors on merits.

anchor.surface_text: it is also well-settled that that even if jurisdiction is so excluded, the civil courts have jurisdiction to examine into cases where the provisions of the Act have not been complied with, or the statutory tribunal has not acted in conformity with the fundamental principles of judicial procedure. It is necessary to add that these observations, though made in somewhat wide terms, do not justify the assumption that if a decision has been made by a taxing authority under the provisions of the relevant taxing statute, its validity can be challenged by a suit on the ground that it is incorrect on the merits

holdings.reasoning_summary: Clarifies scope of Maskim Coy. exception; mere merits error (as here) insufficient; unnecessary to decide exact cases.

holdings.text: Following Raleigh Inv. Co. and Maskim Coy., s.18-A bars civil suits; 'made under this Act' describes provenance, not accuracy.

anchor.surface_text: The next decision to which reference may be made was pronounced by the Privy Council in the case of Releigh Investment Coy. Ltd. v. GovernorGeneral in Council 1 . In that case the effect of s. 67 of the Indian Income-tax Act fell to be considered. ... The phrase made under this Act describes the provenance of the assessment it does not relate to its accuracy in point of law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Analogy to similar provisions in other Acts; scheme of remedies supports.

precedents.citation: State of Andhra Pradesh v. Shri Krishna Cocoanut Co. 1 [1960 1 Andhra W.R.279]

anchor.surface_text: State of Andhra Pradesh v. Shri Krishna Cocoanut Co.  1 , was in favour of the view taken by the trial Court but the respondent urged before the High Court that the said decision was erroneous in law and require reconsideration.

precedents.case_name: State of Andhra Pradesh v. Shri Krishna Cocoanut Co.
precedents.cited_proposition: Suit to recover illegally collected sales tax is competent and not barred by s.18-A

precedents.citation: Secretary of State v. Mask. Coy. 1 [1940 67 I.A. 222,236]

anchor.surface_text: Secretary of State v. Mask. Coy.,  1  the Privy Council was dealing with the effect of the provisions contained in s. 188 of the Sea Customs Act  VIII of 1878 . The relevant portion of the said section provides that every order passed in appeal under this section shall, subject to the power of revision conferred by s. 191, be final.

precedents.case_name: Secretary of State v. Mask & Co.
precedents.cited_proposition: Exclusion of civil courts' jurisdiction not readily inferred, must be explicit or clearly implied; civil courts can examine non-compliance with statute provisions or lack of conformity with fundamental judicial procedure
precedents.cited_holding: it is settled law that the exclusion of the jurisdiction of the civil courts is not to be readily inferred, but that such exclusion must either be explicitly expressed or clearly implied

precedents.citation: Releigh Investment Coy. Ltd. v. GovernorGeneral in Council 1 [1947 74 I.A. 50, 68]

anchor.surface_text: Releigh Investment Coy. Ltd. v. GovernorGeneral in Council  1 . In that case the effect of s. 67 of the Indian Income-tax Act fell to be considered. The said section, inter alia, provides that no suit shall be brought in any civil court to set aside or modify any assessment made under this Act.

precedents.case_name: Raleigh Investment Co. Ltd. v. Governor-General in Council
precedents.cited_proposition: Bar on suits to set aside or modify assessment made under the Act excludes civil jurisdiction where statutory remedies available; 'made under this Act' refers to provenance/origin of assessment, not its accuracy
precedents.cited_holding: the phrase made under this Act describes the provenance of the assessment it does not relate to its accuracy in point of law. The use of the machinery provided by the Act, not the result of that use, is the test

anchor.surface_text: Section 18-A provides that no suit or other Proceeding shall, except as expressly provided in this Act. be instituted in any Court to set aside or modify any assessment made under this Act. It is common ground that there is no express provision made in the Act under which the present suit can be said to have been filed, and so, it falls under the prohibition contained in this section.
The result of these findings was that the respondents appeal was allowed and the appellants suit was dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: The expression any assessment made under this Act is, in our opinion, wide enough to cover all assessments made by the appropriate authorities under this Act whether the said assessments are correct or not. It is the activity of the assessing officer acting as such officer which is intended to be protected and as soon as it is shown that exercising his jurisdiction and authority under this Act, an assessing officer has made an order of assessment that clearly falls within the scope of s.18-A.
The result of these findings was that the respondents appeal was allowed and the appellants suit was dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: Section 11 of the Act provides for appeals to such authority as may be prescribed s. 12 confers revisional jurisdiction on the authorities specified by it s.12-A allows an appeal to the appellate Tribunal s.12-B provides for a provision by the High Court under the cases specified in it s.12-C provides for an appeal to the. High Court and s. I 2-D lays down that petitions, applications and appeals to High Court should be heard by a Bench of not less than two judges. The matter can even be brought to this Court by way of a petition under Art. 136 of the Constitution.
The result of these findings was that the respondents appeal was allowed and the appellants suit was dismissed with costs.
